Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Let me analyze the DECLARE model first Constraints analysis 1 InitR Every trace must start with R 2 ExistenceC Every trace must contain C at least once 3 Responded ExistenceE A If E occurs then A must occur 4 PrecedenceC R C can only occur if R occurred before it 5 NoncoexistenceE C E and C cannot both occur in the same trace

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now the conflicts NoncoexistenceE C says E and C cannot coexist ExistenceC says C must occur Therefore E cannot occur in any trace because if E occurs C cannot occur but C must occur

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Responded ExistenceE A If E occurs A must occur But if E can never occur this is vacuously true but useless

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: the noncoexistence of E and C completely breaks the intended flow R A E P N C because C is final and E in middle If they cant coexist process impossible as intended

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So the anomalies are 1 Logical contradiction ExistenceC NoncoexistenceE C forbids E 2 Vacuous RespondedExistenceE A 3 Missing constraints no enforcement for full sequence A before E etc 4 Insufficient control flow

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Hypotheses 1 Policy contradiction noncoexistence old fasttrack vs existence new policy 2 Misinterpretation noncoexistence meant as precedence or response 3 Data mining artifacts from logs with errors 4 Partial process modeling variants merged wrong

Name: Validation - PE
Text: SQL verification queries 1 Find claims with both E and C violates noncoexistence 2 Claims with C no E satisfies model but skips evaluation 3 Claims with E no C violates existence 4 E without A violates responded existence 5 Full flow compliance check 6 Precedence violations C before R

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Refine SQL to schema Final check DECLARE semantics confirms ExistenceC and NoncoexistenceE C bans E model has no valid traces with E but intended requires E
